s.text: The story is unimportant--some bucolic tale--but the writing is extraordinary, and I must assume that while the art of the original remains, no small credit is due to the translator.

General dictionaries show pronunciations, it is true, but not in the depth displayed in this work [ LPD ], rarely with its precision, and almost never with both American and British pronunciations side by side.

General dictionaries show pronunciations, it is true, but not in the depth displayed in this work [ LPD ], rarely with its precision, and almost never with both American and British pronunciations side by side.
My invariable reply is that the only genuine way to increase one's vocabulary is by reading, reading, reading.
This is the way organism is transcribed in the key; but the text itself shows a full schwa, which indicates that perhaps Wells vacillated on this point himself.
It is probably safe to say that Bill Safire is the most prolific of modern writers on American English; it is very likely true that he is the most prolific writer on language in general.

Professor Mellinkoff traces the verbosity of lawyers to the historical influences of primitive ritual, bilingual duplication, and payment by the word; certainly their Latin and French gave them a running start over competing professions.
Of course, we are not told whose bed.
To wit: first tell them what you are going to say, then tell them what you are saying, and finally tell them what you have said.
